intro: Allium neriniflorum f. albiflorum, commonly known as the white-flowered leek, is a botanical variant of the leek species characterized by its pale to white flowers. It belongs to the Amaryllidaceae family and is native to southern Europe, particularly the Iberian Peninsula. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring long, cylindrical leaves and clusters of small, showy white blooms. It is often cultivated for ornamental purposes due to its elegant appearance and is also used in some culinary applications. This variety is valued for its resilience and ability to thrive in well-drained soils.
